abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Reversal of Land and
            Water Degradation Trends in Lake Chad Basin Ecosystem
            Project for Africa were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to global environment outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            unsatisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in
            complex regional projects, it may be more difficult for the
            implementation and supervision process to fix design flaws.
            To increase the likelihood of achieving project objectives,
            design flaws need to be fixed early in project
            implementation, at minimum during the Mid-term Review (MTR).
            The full endorsement and commitment of all the riparian
            countries of a shared basin is desirable for successful
            Global Environmental Facility- International Waters (GEF-IW)
            project implementation, but not necessary if adequate action
            plans are incorporated in the project design. Country
            management units' and country offices' increased
            involvement in project supervision is critical for the
            regional projects' success. In the absence of a strong
            regional institution, development assistance should focus on
            capacity building and institutional strengthening of the
            recipient, rather than attempting to resolve or bypass the
            institution's shortcomings by introducing outside
            agencies for project management and execution. The Bank
            should be realistic regarding project implementation
            planning, the time it takes to complete a project of this
            challenging nature, and the outcome targets to be achieved.

Africa Region - Reversal of Land and Water
            Degradation Trends in the Lake Chad Basin Ecosystem GEF

abstracts.cdata!:
The Reversal of Land and Water
            Degradation Trends in the Lake Chad Basin Ecosystem Project
            aims to build capacity within the Lake Chad Basin Commission
            and its national committees so that it can better achieve
            its mandate of managing land and water resources in the
            greater conventional basin of Lake Chad. The project has six
            components, three are to be implemented by the United
            Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and, three are to be
            implemented by the World Bank as follows: 1) enhanced
            regional policy initiatives and institutional mechanisms to
            address transboundary issues; 2) creation of regional
            programs and initiation of demonstration projects component
            funds concerning Lake Fitri, the Komadougou-Yobe Basin, and
            Waza-Logone Floodplain and; 3) transboundary diagnostic
            analysis, strategic action plan finalization, and donor coordination.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - Lake Chad Basin (GEF)
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project will ensure that the
            integrity of the Lake Chad system (which involves six
            surrounding countries), is protected by integrated
            management of the basin's resources, by building
            capacity among riparians and stakeholders, completing a
            trans-boundary diagnostic analysis, and preparing a
            strategic action program. However, the degradation of the
            natural resource base, with the consequent impacts on local
            populations, requires an environmental, and social
            assessment. To this end, this environmental assessment,
            based on the appraisals of the Cameroon, and Nigeria Dams
            (v. 1 and 2), and on integrated environmental and social
            assessments (v.3), proposes mitigation measures as follows.
            The rehabilitation, and construction of a wildlife pond in
            Waza, will adversely impact natural habitats, forcing
            wildlife concentrations and an increased localized grazing
            to build pressure around the water point; thus, water points
            should be spread over a greater area, and grazing practices
            limited. Additionally, new water points should avoid upland
            forest areas, to prevent vegetation degradation. Floodplain
            connecting channels will be enlarged and blockages cleared,
            but river flows may be either reduced or increased, thereby
            disturbing ecosystems; engineering/environmental consultants
            should monitor river flows, taking remedial action as
            needed. The identification of critical wetlands for
            conservation will increase pressure on floodplain resources;
            an environmental consultant should monitor soil erosion, and
            review the impacts of conservation on threatened cultivars.
            A process framework for mitigation of social impacts (v. 5)
            provides measures to assist affected populations, following
            an eligibility criteria, and based on public consultations.

TF023579-GEF PDF C - CHAD : PREPARATION
            OF THE LAKE CHAD BASIN PROJECT

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - Lake Chad Basin (GEF)
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project will ensure that the
            integrity of the Lake Chad system (which involves six
            surrounding countries), is protected by integrated
            management of the basin's resources, by building
            capacity among riparians and stakeholders, completing a
            trans-boundary diagnostic analysis, and preparing a
            strategic action program. However, the degradation of the
            natural resource base, with the consequent impacts on local
            populations, requires an environmental, and social
            assessment. To this end, this environmental assessment,
            based on the appraisals of the Cameroon, and Nigeria Dams
            (v. 1 and 2), and on integrated environmental and social
            assessments (v.3), proposes mitigation measures as follows.
            The rehabilitation, and construction of a wildlife pond in
            Waza, will adversely impact natural habitats, forcing
            wildlife concentrations and an increased localized grazing
            to build pressure around the water point; thus, water points
            should be spread over a greater area, and grazing practices
            limited. Additionally, new water points should avoid upland
            forest areas, to prevent vegetation degradation. Floodplain
            connecting channels will be enlarged and blockages cleared,
            but river flows may be either reduced or increased, thereby
            disturbing ecosystems; engineering/environmental consultants
            should monitor river flows, taking remedial action as
            needed. The identification of critical wetlands for
            conservation will increase pressure on floodplain resources;
            an environmental consultant should monitor soil erosion, and
            review the impacts of conservation on threatened cultivars.
            A process framework for mitigation of social impacts (v. 5)
            provides measures to assist affected populations, following
            an eligibility criteria, and based on public consultations.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa Region - Lake Chad Basin (GEF)
            Project : resettlement action plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This resettlement policy framework
            provides mitigation of social impacts resulting from the
            implementation of the Lake Chad Basin Project, and, sets the
            principles of compensation for loss of property, livelihood,
            and relocation or resettlement, of affected populations
            within the six countries of the lake basin. The Lake Chad
            Basin Commission will consult with stakeholders to assess
            adverse social impacts, and plan the resettlement in
            accordance with explicit Bank policies. Compensation for
            land, structures, business and other temporary asset losses
            will be based on market values, productivity valuation,
            negotiated settlements, and labor valuation. It should be
            noted that lack of title, or license would not bar
            compensation, even squatters will be entitled to
            construction costs. In addition, workers losing employment
            in the process of relocating should be entitled to
            transitional income support; and, project affected people
            (PAPs) will also be entitled to transitional assistance,
            i.e., moving expenses, temporary residence, employment
            training and income support, including an option for full
            compensation if duration of impact exceeds two years.
            Compensation will be paid at replacement costs, following
            the establishment of compensation committees, assessment of
            replacement values of identified assets, and establishment
            of compensation rates for assets to be expropriated.
            Compensation committees shall include representation of
            PAPs, to establish adequate rates and avoid litigation;
            however, should grievance prevail a civil court will settle
            the litigation.
